qas.question: DNA from how many Russians show that the Y chromosomes fall into seven major haplogroups all characteristic to West Eurasian populations?
DNA samples from 1228 Russians show that the Y chromosomes analyzed, all except 20 (1.6%) fall into seven major haplogroups all characteristic to what populations?
Taken together, they account for what percentage of the total Russian Y chromosomal pool?
What percentage fell into haplogroups that are specific to East and South Asian populations?
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) examined in Poles and Russians revealed the presence of what major haplogroups?
what percentage of Poles have Y chromosomes in the major haplogroups?
DNA of Poles and Russians differ from what group?
What percentage of Poles have haplogroups from East Asian populations?

context: DNA samples from <a0_0><b6_0>1228<b6_0/><a0_0/> Russians show that the Y chromosomes analyzed, all except 20 (<b5_0>1.6%<b5_0/>) fall into seven major haplogroups all characteristic to <a1_0><b8_0>West Eurasian<b8_0/><a1_0/> populations. Taken together, they account for <a2_0>95%<a2_0/> of the total Russian Y chromosomal pool. Only (<a3_0><b9_0>0.7%<b9_0/><a3_0/>) fell into haplogroups that are specific to East and South Asian populations. Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) examined in Poles and Russians revealed the presence of all major <a4_0>European<a4_0/> haplogroups, which were characterized by similar patterns of distribution in Poles and Russians. An analysis of the DNA did not reveal any specific combinations of unique mtDNA haplotypes and their subclusters. The DNA clearly shows that both Poles and Russians are not different from the <b7_0>neighbouring European populations<b7_0/>.
